title: Lavender Tallow Balm: The Weird Beef Fat Thing That Fixed My Winter Skin
body:
Okay so I need to talk about this beef tallow stuff. The lavender one. My face hasn't felt this... normal in years. It’s winter, my heater is making this weird clicking noise, and everything was just tight and angry. Like that feeling when you smile and your skin might crack. I was scrolling on my phone, my neck hurt from the chair, and I fell into one of those internet holes. You know the ones. Started with “dry skin remedies” and ended up reading about how people in the 1800s used to rub beef fat on their hands. I was like, what? Seriously? But I was desperate. And my grandma, I suddenly remembered, she had this little tin of something she’d put on her knuckles in winter. It smelled like herbs and wax. She never called it tallow, she just called it “the salve.” Anyway. I found this little shop on Etsy, Malti, that makes a whipped tallow balm. With lavender. I figured if I was gonna smear animal fat on my face, it should at least smell nice. So I got it.

I didn’t expect much. Honestly. Beef fat on face sounds like a prank. But it showed up in this simple jar, and I opened it. Smelled like lavender. Not fake candle lavender, but like the dried stuff. Maybe a little earthy underneath. Or maybe that was just my brain knowing it was fat. Texture was weird. Not bad weird. It’s whipped, so it’s like thick cool whip but denser. You scoop a little and it melts the second it touches your skin. Like actually melts. No greasy film, it just… goes away. My skin drank it. That was the first surprise.

## How I Ended Up Putting Beef Fat on My Face

So the history thing. I got curious after I ordered it. Why would anyone think of this? Turns out, tallow skincare isn’t some new hipster thing. It’s ancient. Like, really old. Before lotion in plastic bottles, people used what they had. And tallow—that’s rendered beef fat from around the kidneys—was a big one. It’s stable, doesn’t go rancid fast, and get this: it’s super similar to the oils our own skin makes. Human sebum. So it’s like your skin recognizes it. It doesn’t just sit on top and pretend to moisturize, it actually gets in there. Our great-grandmas and their great-grandmas knew this. They used it for chapped hands, windburn, diaper rash, everything. Then the 20th century happened. We got obsessed with chemicals and factories and making everything new. Tallow got labeled as old-fashioned, gross, primitive. We threw out what worked for something that came in a fancy bottle with a long ingredient list you can’t pronounce. Funny how that works. I was reading this at like 11:47pm, my cat was staring at me, and it just made a sad kind of sense. We forgot a lot of simple stuff.

## What This Lavender Tallow Balm Actually Does

So back to the jar on my nightstand. Night cream, they said. Calming. Sleep-promoting. I was skeptical about that part too. I’ve had lavender stuff before. Sometimes it smells like a cheap air freshener. This is different. It’s a quiet smell. Herbal. Timeless, I guess. I put it on after I wash my face at night. The ritual of it, scooping a little, warming it between my fingers, it’s… I don’t know. It makes me slow down. My brain goes from a million things to just this one thing. My skin feels cool for a second, then just soft. Not “soft to the touch” soft, but like… hydrated. My face doesn’t feel thirsty anymore. I started using it on my hands too because why not. I wash my hands a million times a day. They were a mess. Red, cracked at the knuckles. After a few days of putting this on at night with socks over my hands like a weirdo, the cracks healed. Actually healed. I didn’t buy a special hand cream. I just used the same jar. It’s good for dry skin, they said. Yeah. Understatement.

The fine lines thing. I’m in my 30s. I have those little lines by my eyes from smiling. I wasn’t using this to fight wrinkles, I was using it to not feel like a lizard. But I looked in the mirror one morning after maybe two weeks and I was like… huh. My skin just looked… calm. Plump. Not puffy, just like it had enough water. The lines were still there, I’m not selling magic here, but they looked less like cracks in a desert and more like just… part of my face. It’s made in France, this stuff, from grass-fed cows. I guess that matters. Purity or whatever. All I know is it sinks in and doesn’t make me break out. My skin is sensitive. Like, “that new detergent gave me a rash” sensitive. This did nothing but help.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of This Stuff

So it’s been a month maybe. Maybe more. I lost track. I use it every night. Sometimes in the morning if it’s really cold. My winter routine is now: wash face, tallow balm. That’s it. I have a cabinet full of serums and creams that cost way more, and they’re just sitting there. I feel a little guilty but also not. Because this works. Like actually works. My partner even noticed. He was like, “Your face looks… good.” Which is high praise. He said my skin looked “clear.” Not shiny, not greasy. Just clear. My elbows haven’t been this smooth since… I don’t know when. I used to scratch them in my sleep because they were so dry. That stopped.

Here’s the weird part. It’s not a miracle. It’s not a “game-changer” in that dramatic before-and-after ad way. It’s subtler. It’s like your skin just finally has what it needs, so it stops freaking out. No more tightness after a shower. No more foundation clinging to dry patches. It’s just… normal skin. Which feels like a miracle after years of it not being normal. I told my mom about it. She laughed at first. “Tallow? Like candle making?” But then she tried some on her hands when she visited. She took the jar info. I’m on my second jar now. I got one for my mom too. From that same Etsy shop, Malti. It’s just a small operation, I think. The jar is simple. No crazy packaging. You’re paying for the stuff inside.

## Would I Buy This Lavender Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. Obviously. I already did. I’m probably gonna order another one soon so I don’t run out. It’s become a non-negotiable. Like toothpaste. I travel with it. I put a little in a contact lens case for weekends away. It feels like a secret. An old, simple secret that everyone forgot about. There’s this whole natural skincare comeback happening, people looking for stuff that’s real, with ingredients you can understand. Tallow is like the OG of that. It’s just one ingredient, really, plus some essential oils for scent. That’s it. No water, no preservatives, no fillers. It’s concentrated so you use a tiny bit. This little jar lasts forever.

Anyway. If your skin is being difficult, especially in this dry winter air, it might be worth a shot. If you can get past the “beef fat” idea. Think of it as traditional tallow skincare. A natural skincare comeback that actually makes sense. It’s not weird when you think about the history of it. We’re the weird ones for using plastic bottles of chemical soup.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, it sounds wild but it is. Because it’s so close to the oils our skin makes naturally, it absorbs deep instead of sitting on top. It’s like giving your skin something it recognizes. Good for sensitive skin, dry skin, all of it.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Nope. That was my biggest worry. Comedogenic ratings are weird, but tallow is generally non-comedogenic. It melts right in. My face feels clear, not clogged. If anything, my skin is less angry so I get fewer random bumps.

**What does the lavender tallow balm smell like?**
It smells like real lavender. Herbal, a little earthy, not sweet or perfumey. It’s calming. The smell doesn’t stick around all night, it’s just there when you put it on. It’s nice. Makes the whole thing feel like a ritual.

So yeah. That’s my take. My skin’s happy, I’m happy. I don’t know what else to say. It just works. If you’re curious about this whole traditional tallow skincare thing, this lavender balm is a pretty good place to start.
